newsitem.title: CHINA: Malaysia's Perwaja withdraws FRN, plans another.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia's Perwaja withdraws FRN, plans another.

text.p: Malaysian company Perwaja Terengganu's recently launched US$400 million floating rate note issue has been withdrawn, but another deal is planned.
The issue, which was guaranteed by the government of Malaysia, was withdrawn by the issuer and the guarantor, arranger Standard Chartered Bank said on Thursday.
Standard Chartered Bank has been mandated to arrange a new FRN issue with amended terms and conditions, the bank said.
The issue that was withdrawn had a final maturity of five years. It paid a coupon of 22 basis points and five basis points in fees.
A new issue could be launched as early as Friday, bankers said.

Perwaja, a state-owned insolvent steel maker, was found last year to have accumulated losses of 2.5 billion ringgit in losses and its previous government-appointed managers were investigated for financial mismanagement.
The government is now trying to privatize the company.
Despite the company's difficulties, bankers have shown some interest in the transaction because of the government guarantee. Investment-grade Malaysia generally is very popular with investors.
Bankers speculated that the issuer and the guarantor may have pulled the deal with the idea of negotiating more advantageous terms.
